speech: 10 years. I want to say something about foreign policy, which is this. We keep acting as if we’re in the 20th century or the 19th century. If you look at the biggest threats to the United States, we’re talking right now about coronavirus that cannot be solved within the borders of the United States. We’re talking about climate change, which is a global problem where we need US leadership for countries around the world. In fact, Mr. Trump’s policy of us going it alone, of America First, of having no values, no allies, and no strategy, is disastrous for us. The biggest threat to America right now, in terms of our safety of our citizens, is climate, and it’s time for us to deal with it that way.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Thank you, Mr. Steyer.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Tom Steyer
speech: Every single foreign policy issue is about American leadership-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: The next-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Tom Steyer
speech: -and coalition.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: New topic. Senator Sanders. You’ve praised-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Can I say one word-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: It’s in the same theme, sir. You’ve praised the Chinese Communist Party for lifting more people out of extreme poverty than any other country. You also have a track record of expressing sympathy for socialist governments in Cuba and in Nicaragua. Can Americans trust that a Democratic Socialist president will not give authoritarians a free pass?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: I have opposed authoritarianism all over the world, and I was really amazed at what Mayor Bloomberg just said a moment ago. He said that the Chinese government is responsive to the Politburo. But who the hell is the Politburo responsive to? Who elects the Politburo? You got a real dictatorship there. Of course you have a dictatorship in Cuba. What I said is what Barack Obama said, in terms of Cuba: that Cuba made progress on education. Yes. I think-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Speaker 1
speech: Boo!

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Really? Really?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Yes, because there’s no comparing those two commentaries.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Literacy programs are bad? What Barack Obama said is-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: What Barack Obama was doing was opening diplomatic doors. What you were doing is making excuses.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: -they made great progress on education and healthcare. That was Barack Obama. Occasionally-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: I’ve talked to Barack Obama.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Excuse me. Occasionally, it might be a good idea to be honest about American foreign policy, and that includes the fact that America has overthrown governments all over the world, in Chile, in Guatemala, in Iran. And when dictatorships, whether it is the Chinese or the Cubans, do something good-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Time.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: -you acknowledge that.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Time. Mr. Vice President-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: But you don’t have to trade love letters with them.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Vice President Biden, would you like-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: This is 2020. We can’t be reliving the Cold War.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Mr. Vice President.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: [crosstalk 00:15:23] Look, Barack Obama was abroad. He was in a town meeting. He did not in any way suggest that there was anything positive about the Cuban government. He acknowledged that they did increase life expectancy, but he went on and condemned the dictatorship. He went on and condemned the people who in fact had run that committee. He also made sure to make it clear… And by the way, I called to make sure that I was prepared to… I never say my private conversations with him. But the fact of the matter is, he in fact does not, did not, has never embraced an authoritarian regime, and does not now.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Okay.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: This man said that, in fact, that he did not condemn-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: … man said that in fact he thought it was… He did not condemn what they did.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: That is untrue, categorically untrue.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: What did you tell him?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: I have condemned authoritarianism, whether it is the people in Saudi Arabia, that the United States government has loved for years.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: How about Cuba and Nicaragua?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Cuba, Nicaragua, authoritarianism of any stripe is bad.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: Period.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: That is different than saying that governments occasionally do things that are good.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: Oh, come on.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Look at what Barack Obama said about international [crosstalk 00:16:30].

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Could I, as the person, Buttigieg.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: The only way you can do this is to actually win the presidency, and I am not looking forward to a scenario where it comes down to Donald Trump with his nostalgia for the social order of the 1950s, and Bernie Sanders with the nostalgia for the revolutionary politics of the 1960s. This is not about what cous were happening in the 1970s or ’80s, this is about the future. This is about 2020. We are not going to survive or succeed, and they’re certainly not going to win by reliving the Cold War, and we’re not going to win these critical, critical House and Senate races, if people in those races have to explain why the nominee of the democratic party is telling people to look at the bright side of the Castro regime. We’ve got to be a lot smarter about this and look to the future.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Senator Sanders, your response?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Let us be clear. Do we think healthcare for all, Pete, is some kind of radical communist idea?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Glad you brought this up. Let’s talk about that.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Do we think raising the minimum wage to a living wage-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: I’m happy to respond to the question, because this is really important.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Do we think building the millions of units of affordable housing-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: No, if you’re going to ask that rhetorical question, let’s go behind the-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Do we think raising taxes on billionaires is a radical idea.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Let’s talk about what’s radical about that plan. Senator, please.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Do you think criminal justice reform is a radical idea?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Senator, the things you just named are the things we favor but, the way you’re talking about doing it is radical by-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: The truth is-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: One at a time.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Pete, the American people support my agenda, that is why I am beating Trump in virtually every poll, and is why I will defeat him.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: we’ve got to open this up. Universal healthcare for example.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Senator Klobuchar.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: Donald Trump’s, Bernie, Donald Trump’s worst nightmare is having someone that the people in the middle, who are tired of the insults, and the extremes in our politics have someone to vote for. And I was going to comment on Cuba policy, because I actually lead the bill to lift the embargo. I went with Barack Obama when he went to Cuba, and I’ve seen firsthand how the Cuban people are way in front of their leaders. They like America, they want to be entrepreneurs, and the way that we embrace them and not the socialist regime is by opening up Cuba, and starting to do business with them. But to get at what we were just talking about, I just think we have a huge choice. Super Tuesday States, one third of America will vote. Do you want to have someone in charge of this ticket?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Thank you Senator.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: Could I finish Margaret?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Well, you’re at time, Senator.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: We want to have someone in charge of this ticket who wants to put forward $60 trillion in spending three times the American economy? I don’t think we do. I think that we can get all those bold, progressive things done without having someone that is so alienating, that we’re going to turn off the voters that we need to bring in.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: You have to allow this Senator to respond. Senator Peter-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: I’ve got to respond to the question that Senator Sanders-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Amy used the word alienating. Hey Amy, my favorability nationally, I believe are the highest up here, as a matter of fact. But the point is, the way we are going to beat Trump, which is what everybody up here wants, is we need a campaign of energy and excitement. We need to have the largest voter turnout in the history of the United States. We need to bring working people back into the democratic party. We need to get young people voting in a way they have never done before. That is what our campaign is about.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Bill Whitaker has the floor.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bill Whitaker
speech: Vice President Biden.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: Yes.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bill Whitaker
speech: The bipartisan Senate Select Committee on intelligence report concluded Russia interfered in our last presidential election. And the Obama Administration failed to respond forcefully. US intelligence says Russia’s at it again. If it is proven that Russia has interfered in the 2020 elections, would you as president launch a retaliatory cyber attack?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: I would make them pay for it, and I’d make them pay for it economic, they are engaged now, as I speak, in interfering in our election. They were engaged, when in fact, we were, the last election in 2016, against Hillary. They were. There’s no question. This man stood before the whole world, turned to the Russian leader, and said, “Why in God’s name would this man ever interfere in our elections?” Give me a break. 17 intelligence agencies said he did. When we got the information, we went to the committee in the Senate that’s responsible for knowing these issues and dealing with them. We went to Mitch McConnell and said, “Join us, and point out what is happening here.” He said, “No, we want no part of it.” And if we had moved, we didn’t have all the information at that time, until after the election was over. And so the idea the bipartisan committee said we could have done more, theoretically that’s true, but the fact of the matter is, we didn’t have the information, until the end. And so look, we in fact should be imposing sanctions on Russia now, for their interference.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bill Whitaker
speech: Mr. Steyer.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Tom Steyer
speech: Look. 21st century warfare is cyber warfare. What we’re having is an attack by a hostile foreign power on our democracy right now. The question you have to ask is, where’s the commander- in-chief? And let me say this-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: We don’t have one.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Tom Steyer
speech: This isn’t news. What vice president Biden said is true. He did stand next to Vladimir Putin. There was a hostile foreign attack on our election last time, and the president sided with the hostile foreign power. That’s why I started need to impeach. That’s what we have to do. We have to oppose a president who sides with a hostile foreign power, that commits cyber warfare against the United States of America. That’s where we are. Where are all these patriotic Republicans who wave the flag, but when we’re actually under attack, they side with our enemies? It’s outrageous. That’s why he should have been impeached. They covered it up, and I was years before these people. There’s something wrong here. We’re under attack, and they’re not doing a darn thing about it.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bill Whitaker
speech: Thank you Mr. Steyer. Major.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Major Garrett
speech: Senator Sanders. Senator Sanders, I have a question for you sir. You’re the front runner in this race. You’re on the ballot in South Carolina. Mayor Bloomberg, you’ll understand that preamble in just a second. If elected, Senator Sanders, you would be America’s first Jewish president. You recently called a very prominent, well-known American Israel lobby, a platform for quote, bigotry. What would you say to American Jews who might be concerned you’re not from their perspective, supportive enough of Israel and specifically, sir, would you move the US Embassy back to Tel Aviv?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Let me just, the answer is, it’s something that we would take into consideration. But here is the point. I am very proud of being Jewish. I actually lived in Israel for some months, but what I happen to believe is that right now, sadly, tragically, in Israel, through Bibi Netanyahu, you have a reactionary racist who is now running that country. And I happen to believe, I happen to believe, that what our foreign policy in the mid-east should be about is absolutely protecting the independence and security of Israel. But you cannot ignore the suffering of the Palestinian people. We have got to have a policy that reaches out to the Palestinians, and the Americans. And in answer to your question, that will come within the context of bringing nations together in the mid-east.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Major Garrett
speech: Mayor Bloomberg, would you like to weigh in on that please?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
speech: Well, the battles been going on for a long time in the Middle East, whether it’s the Arabs versus the Persians, the Shias versus the Sunnis, the Jews in Israel and the Palestinians, it’s only gone on for 40 or 50 years. Number one, you can’t move the embassy back. We should not have done it without getting something from the Israeli government, but it was done, and you’re going to have to leave it there. Number two, only solution here is a two state solution. The Palestinians have to be accommodated. The real problem here is you have two groups of people, both of who think God them the same piece of land. And the answer is to obviously split it up, leave the Israeli borders where they are. Try to push them to pull back some of those extra, over on the other side of the wall where they’ve built these new communities, which they should not have done that. Pull it back-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Major Garrett
speech: Mayor Bloomberg, thank you very much. Senator Warren.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: Look, the way we have to think about this is I think we have to start with the values, and what has to be protected here. Israelis have a right to security, and the Palestinians have a right to be treated with dignity and to have self determination. That is a two state solution, but it’s not up to us to determine what the terms of a two state solution are. We want to be a good ally to everyone in the region. The best way to do that is to encourage the parties to get to the negotiating table themselves. Donald Trump’s big mistake is he keeps putting a thumb on the scale on just one side. And that moves the parties further away from working out their own solution here. We need to be an ally, by supporting them to come to negotiate to find a lasting peace.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Major Garrett
speech: But Senator Warren, just on the question of the embassy, what was your position on that?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: It is not ours to do.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Major Garrett
speech: Would you move it back?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: It is not ours to do. We should let the parties determine the capitals themselves.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Major Garrett
speech: Norah?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Norah O’Donnell
speech: I want to turn now to the issue of North Korea, because President Trump has engaged in a direct diplomacy meeting directly with Kim Jong-un. Senator Klobuchar, if you were commander-in-chief, would you meet with the North Korean leader?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: I would, but not in the way this president has done it. He literally thinks he can go over and bring a hot dish to the dictator next door, and he thinks everything’s going to be fine. He has not done it with our allies. He has literally just hastily called summit and run off. That is no way to do it, and as you can see, North Korea is emboldened. They’re still launching missiles. They promised a Christmas surprise that thankfully never happened, and he has not been able to advance the ball at all. So what would I do? I would work with our allies. And it has been pointed out, this is what this president fails at all the time.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: We should be negotiating ourselves back into the Iran Nuclear Agreement. We should be working with Russia, not only to stand up for the protection of our elections, and call Vladimir Putin out for what he is, the ruthless dictator that takes down planes, that poisons dissidence, but that also at the same time, we have to acknowledge that we should be renegotiating the New Start Treaty, and the other arms negotiations that must happen. This president just likes to do tweets at 4:00 AM in his bathrobe, gets out there, and doesn’t achieve the results we need. I would meet with him, but I would do it with our allies. I would have clear deliverables, and I would achieve those deliverables.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Norah O’Donnell
speech: Senator Klobuchar, thank you. Mr vice president, how would you deal with North Korea?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: You don’t negotiate with a dictator, give him legitimacy, without any notion whether he is going to do anything at all. You don’t do that. Look what happened. He gave this dictator, he’s a thug, legitimacy. We’ve weakened the sanctions around the world against holding us, committing people not to trade, benefiting from oil to parts that they can deal with, providing missile technology. And what’s happened? It’s been weakened. I would be in Beijing, I would be calling to, I would be speaking with Xi Jinping, I would be reassigning the relationship between Japan and South Korea, and I would make it clear. I would make it clear to China. We are going to continue to move closer to make sure that we can in fact prevent China, prevent North Korea, from launching missiles, to take them down. And if we don’t, why am I stopping? No one else stops.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Norah O’Donnell
speech: Okay.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: It’s my Catholic school training.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Norah O’Donnell
speech: Okay.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Vice president Biden, you’re a gentleman. Good home training, Thank you sir.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: Gentlemen don’t get very well treated up here.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Norah O’Donnell
speech: Margaret Brennan.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Thank you very much. Norah. This is a question for Mayor Buttigieg. As you know, viewers and voters are participating in this through Twitter. The city of Idlib in Syria is facing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis. The Syrian regime and Russia are targeting schools, bakeries, and hospitals. What would you do as president to push back regime, and Russian forces, and stop the killing of innocent civilians?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: First of all, I stand with the people of Idlib, who are being targeted, as you said, in a brutal fashion by a dictatorship that has already been so brutal for so many years. And this is one of the reasons we have got to change the balance of power in the region, because the president has basically vanished from the stage, when it comes to even playing a role in the future there. Turkey, Russia, Iran, all have so much more of a say than we do. We don’t have to be invading countries to be making a difference working with our international partners in order to deliver peace, and support those who are standing up for self-determination. Now I want to come back to something, and I promise it relates to international affairs, because Senator Sanders asked me a question earlier. He asked the question of whether healthcare for everybody is a radical idea. And it’s not, which is why I’m for it, very much in a different way though. What is a radical idea is completely eliminating all private insurance. And part of how you know it is, is that no industrialized country has gone that far.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: He and I both like to talk about Denmark for example, but even in Denmark, they have not abolished the possibility of private insurance. So this is an idea that goes further than what is acceptable in Denmark, the country, let alone imagining how that’s going to fly in Denmark, South Carolina.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Thank you Mayor.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Can I respond?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Senator Warren-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Can I respond to that?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Senator Warren, would you like to respond? What would Senator Warren do to stop the mass murder?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: I’m sorry.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Same question. What would you do to stop the mass murder in Idlib, Syria?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: Look, I think that what we’ve got to do is we have to provide humanitarian relief. We need to work with our allies on this, but this is not a moment for military intervention. We have got to use our military, only when we see a military problem that can be solved militarily. We cannot send our military in unless we have a plan to get them out. So for me, this is about working with our allies. It is about standing with the people, who are under enormous pressure right now. This is recognizing what Donald Trump has put us in, in a terrible box around the world. But the solution is not to use our military. The solution is to use the other tools here.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Thank you, senator. We’ve talked a lot about your policies during this debate. Now we’d like to get a little more personal. I know Senator Sanders, how much you enjoy that. We’re going to ask you when we come back from the break about the words you live by. We’re going to give you a couple of minutes to gather your thoughts. We’ll be right back.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Welcome back to Charleston, South Carolina. This is the final segment of the final debate before the first in the South primary this Saturday and super Tuesday, one week from today, Gail.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: All right, one final question, candidates, and it’s a two parter. First, I’d like you each to tell us the biggest misconception about you. That’s number one. Number two, the South Carolina motto is this, while I breathe, I hope. So outside of politics and no more than 45 seconds or so, what is your personal motto, your personal belief, your favorite quote that represents you? Mr. Steyer, The biggest misconception and then your motto.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Tom Steyer
speech: The biggest misconception about me is that it’s somehow I’m defined by business success and money.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Okay. And your motto?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Tom Steyer
speech: My motto, every day I write a cross on my hand to remind myself to tell the truth and do what’s right no matter what.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: All right, thank you Mr. Steyer. Senator Klobuchar.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: I’d say the biggest … The biggest misconception is that I’m boring, because I’m not. I would say that my motto is the words of one of my political mentors, Paul Wellstone, who’s sadly no longer with us. And he said that politics is about improving people’s lives. And that’s been my life from when my grandpa was an iron ore miner and the union’s politics made them those mines safer. And when my dad needed treatment, it was there for him, and in his words, he was pursued by grace. And when my mom got divorced and she didn’t have a job and she went back to teaching and that gift of public service got her through. And then when our daughter was born-

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Senator Klobuchar, I’m sorry, what was your motto? I’m sorry, what was your motto?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: Oh, I thought we had a minute to answer the question.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: What was your motto? I’m sorry.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: My motto was that politics is about improving people’s lives.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Got it. Got it. Vice President Biden? Biggest misconception.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: Pretty good one.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: It was very good one. Very good one. Thank you.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: When you get knocked down, get up and everyone’s entitled to be treated with dignity no matter what. No matter who they are. Mine also that everyone should be represented. That no one’s better than me and I’m no better than anyone else. The fact is what we should be doing we talked about the Supreme Court. I’m looking forward to making sure there’s a black woman on the Supreme Court to make sure [inaudible 00:39:57]. Not a joke, not a joke. I pushed very hard for that.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Vice President.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: My mother’s motto was, she said, “You’re defined by your courage or redeemed by your loyalty.” I am loyal. I do what I say.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: What’s the biggest misconception about you, sir?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: I have more hair than I think I do.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: There’s a way to fix that. Senator Sanders.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Misconception.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Yes.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Misconception, and you’re hearing it here tonight, is that the ideas I’m talking about are radical. They’re not. In one form or another, they exist in countries all over the world. Healthcare is a human right. We have the necessity, the moral imperative to address the existential threat of climate change. Other countries are doing that. We don’t need more people in jail, disproportionately African American, than any other country on earth. Not a radical idea. The motto, the saying that that moves me the most is from Nelson Mandela and Mandela said, “Everything is impossible until it happens.” And that means, if we have the guts to stand up to powerful special interest, we’re doing phenomenally well. If we can bring working people together, black and white and Latino, we can create a nation.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: All right, Senator, thank you.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Where all people have a good standard of living.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Senator Warren.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: Well, I suppose one misconception is that I don’t eat very much. In fact, I eat all the time, because I get teased about this. Look, I never was supposed to be on a stage like this and the misconception is that I thought I should be president of the United States. No, I got into this because I am a fighter. My motto ties in directly to this. It’s Matthew 25 and that is in as much as she hath done it into one of these, the least of thy brethren, ye have done it unto me. For me, this is about how we treat other people and how we lift them up. That is why I am in this fight. That is why I am running to be president and it is why I will be an effective president.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Thank you, Senator. Now Buttigieg.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: I think the biggest conception misconception is that I’m not passionate. I get that I’m kind of level. Some say unflappable. I don’t think you want a president who’s flappable, but it’s precisely because I’m so passionate about the things that are going on in this country that I consider it important to approach all of that with discipline. And my disciplines are guided by the motto is I try to live by, many of which come from scripture. And just to be clear, I would never impose my interpretation of my religion on anybody.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Just to sure as I’m wearing this ring, I’ll never let that happen to anybody. But I seek to live by the teachings that say that if you would be a leader, you must first be a servant. And of course the teaching not unique to the Christian tradition, but a big part of it that holds that we are to treat others as we would be treated. And when I think about everything at stake, from racial and economic justice, to our stewardship of the climate, to the need to heal the sick, and the need to heal this country, I seek for those teachings to order my steps as I go through this campaign, and as I go through life.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: Thank you. Mayor Bloomberg?

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
speech: Misconception that I’m six feet tall, and quote, I’ve trained for this job for a long time and when I get it, I’m going to do something rather than just talk about it.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Thank you candidates. Thank you very much.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Well, thank you. That concludes our debate.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Though we have time for one more break, Norah, one more break. Time flies when you’re having fun. You’re watching the democratic debate right here on CBS.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: Thank you. That concludes our debate. We want to thank the candidates, the moderators, and to you watching at home tonight.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: And a reminder that the primary here in South Carolina is this Saturday, the next Tuesday, of course, super Tuesday, CBS news will have special coverage.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: And our coverage of tonight’s debate will continue in a moment from the spin room here on CBS and on our streaming news service, CBSN. There’ll be more about the debate as well on your late local news on this CBS station and first thing tomorrow on CBS this morning.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: I’m getting on a plane right now, going to New York. I’ll be there.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Margaret Brennan
speech: From all of us here at CBS news, I’m Norah O’Donnell. Goodnight.

debate_name: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript: February 25 Democratic Debate
debate_section: Part 3: South Carolina Democratic Debate Transcript
speaker: Gayle King
speech: Goodnight.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Lester Holt
speech: Good evening everyone. I’m Lester Holt. Welcome to Las Vegas. Everything is on the line tonight, with just three days before the critical Nevada caucuses. Here with me on the stage tonight, NBC News Political Director and moderator of Meet the Press, Chuck Todd. And NBC News Chief White House correspondent and MSNBC anchor, Hallie Jackson. Also joining us is Telemundo’s Senior Correspondent, Vanessa Hauc. And editor of the Nevada Independent Jon Ralston, who has covered Nevada politics for more than three decades. The rules are this tonight, candidates will get a minute 15 to answer each question and 45 seconds for followups. Now that the stage has narrowed to six candidates, we encourage each of you to directly engage with each other on the issues.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Lester Holt
speech: So let’s get to our first question. Since the last time you all shared the stage, Senator Sanders, a self-described democratic socialist, has surged into the lead nationally in the democratic race. And there’s a new person on the stage tonight, Mayor Michael Bloomberg. A former Republican who spent millions of his own dollars to run in this race. What hasn’t changed? A majority of democratic voters still say their top priority is beating President Trump. Senator Sanders, the first question to you, Mayor Bloomberg is pitching himself as a centrist who says he’s best positioned to win in November. Why is your revolution a better bet?

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: In order to beat Donald Trump, we’re going to need the largest voter turnout in the history of the United States. Mr. Bloomberg had policies in New York city of stop-and-frisk, which went after African American and Latino people in an outrageous way. That is not a way you’re going to grow voter turnout. What our movement is about is bringing working class people together, black and white and Latino, Native American, Asian American, around an agenda that works for all of us and not just the billionaire class. And that agenda says that maybe, just maybe, we should join the rest of the industrialized world, guarantee healthcare to all people as a human right, raise that minimum wage to a living wage of 15 bucks an hour. And have the guts to take on the fossil fuel industry, because their short term profits are not more important than the future of this planet and the need to combat climate change. Those are some of the reasons we have the strongest campaign to defeat Donald Trump.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: So I’d like-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Lester Holt
speech: Mayor Bloomberg, can Senator Sanders beat President Trump and how do you want to respond to what else he said?

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
speech: I don’t think there’s any chance of the Senator beating President Trump. You don’t start out by saying, “I’ve got 160 million people, I’m going to take away the insurance plan that they love.” That’s just not a ways that you go and start building the coalition that the Sanders’ camp thinks that they can do. I don’t think there’s any chance whatsoever, and if he goes and is the candidate, we will have Donald Trump for another four years and we can’t stand that.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Lester Holt
speech: Senator Warren.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: I’d like to talk about who we’re running against. A billionaire who calls women fat broads and horse faced lesbians. And no, I’m not talking about Donald Trump, I’m talking about mayor Bloomberg. Democrats are not going to win if we have a nominee who has a history of hiding his tax returns, of harassing women and of supporting racist policies like redlining and stop-and-frisk. Look, I’ll support whoever the democratic nominee is, but understand this, Democrats take a huge risk if we just substitute one arrogant billionaire for another. This country has worked for the rich for a long time and left everyone else in the dirt. It is time to have a president who will be on the side of working families and be willing to get out there and fight for them. That is why I am in this race and that is how I will beat Donald Trump.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Lester Holt
speech: [crosstalk 00:04:14] Senator Klobuchar, what do you think the path is from this stage to the White House? What works?

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: I think the path is a high voter turnout. I’m the one on this stage that had the highest voter turnout of any state in the country, when I led the tip ticket. As well as bringing in rural and suburban voters and I’ve done that as well. And I’m the only one with the receipts to have done that in Republican congressional districts over and over again. But I want to say this, I actually welcomed Mayor Bloomberg to the stage. I thought that he shouldn’t be hiding behind his TV ads, and so I was already for this big day. And then I looked at the memo from his campaign staff this morning and it said that he actually thought that three of us should get out of the way. That is what his campaign said, because we should pave the way for him to become the nominee.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: I have been told as a woman, as someone that maybe no one thought was still going to be standing up on this stage, but I am because of pure grit and because of the people out there. I’ve been told many times to wait my turn and to step aside and I’m not going to do that now and I’m not going to do that because a campaign memo from Mayor Bloomberg said this morning that the only way that we get a nominee is if we step aside for him. I think we need something different than Donald Trump. I don’t think you look at Donald Trump and say, we need someone richer in the white house.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Lester Holt
speech: Thank you. Mayor Bloomberg, there’s a lot for you to respond to there, so here’s your opportunity.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
speech: I think we have two questions to face tonight. One is, who can beat Donald Trump? And number two, who can do the job if they get into the White House? And I would argue that I am candidate that can do exactly both of those things. I’m a New Yorker. I know how to take on an arrogant con man like Donald Trump that comes from New York. I’m a mayor. I was a mayor. I know how to run a complicated city, the biggest, most diverse city in this country. I’m a manager. I knew what to do after 9-11 and brought the city back stronger than ever. And I’m a philanthropist who didn’t inherit his money, but made his money. And I’m spending that money to get rid of Donald Trump, the worst President we have ever had. And if I can get that done, it will be a great contribution to America and to my kids.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Lester Holt
speech: Vice President Biden, I’ll let you weigh in there.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: In terms who can beat Donald Trump, NBC did a poll yesterday, says Joe Biden is best equipped to beat Donald Trump. That’s what your poll said. And it said that I can beat him in those toss up states too, those states we have to win. I’m ahead by eight points across the board. So in terms of being able to beat Donald Trump, I’m better positioned according to your poll than anybody else to beat Donald Trump, number one. Number two, the Mayor makes an interesting point. The mayor says that he has a great record, that he’s done these wonderful things.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Joe Biden
speech: Well the fact of the matter is, he has not managed his city very, very well when he was there. He didn’t get a whole lot done. He has stop-and-frisk, throwing close to 5 million young black men up against a wall. And when we came along in our administration, President Obama and said, “We’re going to send in a mediator to stop it.” He said, “That’s unnecessary.” So we’re going to get a chance to talk about the mayor’s record, but in terms of who is best prepared to beat Donald Trump, look at your poll and what it says.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Lester Holt
speech: Mayor Buttigieg, you’d like to weigh in.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Yes, we’ve got to wake up as a party. We could wake up two weeks from today, the day after super Tuesday, and the only candidates left standing will be Bernie Sanders and Mike Bloomberg, the two most polarizing figures on this stage. And most Americans don’t see where they fit, if they’ve got to choose between a socialist who thinks that capitalism is the root of all evil and a billionaire who thinks that money ought to be the root of all power. Let’s put forward somebody who actually lives and works in a middle-class neighborhood, in an industrial Midwestern city. Let’s put forward somebody who’s actually a Democrat. Look, we shouldn’t have to choose between one candidate who wants to burn this party down and another candidate who wants to buy this party out. We can do better.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Lester Holt
speech: Senator Sanders, are you polarizing?

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: If speaking to the needs and the pain of a long neglected working class is polarizing, I think you got the wrong word. What we are trying finally to do, is to give a voice to people who have to 45 years of work are not making a nickel more than they did 45 years ago. We are giving a voice to people who are saying we are sick of tired of billionaires like Mr. Bloomberg seeing huge expansions of their wealth, while a half a million people sleep out on the street tonight. And that’s what we are saying, Pete, is maybe it’s a time for the working class of this country to have a little bit of power in Washington rather than your billionaire campaign contributors.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: All right. Look, first of all- [crosstalk 00:09:43] Look, my campaign is fueled by hundreds of thousands of contributors-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Including 46 billionaires.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Among the hundreds of thousands of contributors. And look, we’ve got to unite this country to deal with these issues. You’re not the only one who cares about the working class. Most Americans believe we need to empower workers. As a matter of fact, you’re the one who is at war with the Culinary Union right here in Las Vegas. We can’t-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: We are more union support than you have ever dreamed of.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: We can-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: We have the support of unions all across this country.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Yeah but the vision I’m putting forward has the support of the American people.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Really.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: We can actually deliver healthcare without taking it away from anyone. We can actually empower workers and lift wages without further polarizing this country and we can build a movement without having legions of our supporters online and in person attacking democratic figures and union leaders alike-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Hallie Jackson
speech: Senator Warren, I have a question for you. On Sunday, on Meet the Press, Vice President Biden accused Senator Sanders supporters of bullying union leaders here with, “Vicious, malicious misogynistic things.” You said Democrats cannot build an inclusive party on a foundation of hate. Are Senator Sanders and his supporters making it harder for Democrats to unify in November?

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: Look, I have said many times before, we are all responsible for our supporters. And we need to step up, that’s what leadership is all about. But the way we are going to lead this country and beat Donald Trump is going to be with a candidate who has rock solid values and who actually gets something done. When Mayor Bloomberg was busy blaming African Americans and Latinos for the housing crash of 2008, I was right here in Las Vegas, literally just a few blocks down the street holding hearings on the banks that were taking away homes from millions of families.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: That’s when I met Mr. Estrada, one of your neighbors. He came in to testify and he said he thought he’d done everything right with Wells Fargo. But what had happened? They took away his house in a matter of weeks. This man stood there and cried while he talked about what it was like to tell his two little daughters that they might not be in their elementary schools, that they might be living out of their van. I spent the next years making sure that would never happen again. Wall Street fought us every inch of the way on a consumer agency. They lost and I won. We need a candidate with unshakeable values and a candidate who can actually get something done for working people. That’s why I’m in this race-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Hallie Jackson
speech: Senator, thank you.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: And that’s how I’ll beat Donald Trump.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Hallie Jackson
speech: Senator Sanders.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: We have over 10.6 million people on Twitter and 99.9% of them are decent human beings, are working people, are people who believe in justice, compassion and love. And if there are a few people who make ugly remarks, who attack trade union leaders, I disowned those people, they are not part of our movement. But let me also say, what I hope my friends up here will agree with, is that if you look at the wild West of the internet, talk to some of the African American women on my campaign, talk to Senator Nina Turner, talk to others and find the vicious racist, sexist attacks that are coming their way as well. So I would hope that all of us understand that we should do everything we possibly can to end the viciousness and ugliness on the internet. Our campaign is about issues. It’s about fighting for the working families and the middle class. It is not about vicious attacks on other people.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Senator, when you say that you disown these attacks and you didn’t personally direct them, I believe you.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Well thank you.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: But at a certain point you got to ask yourself, why did this pattern arise? Why is it especially the case among your supporters that this happens?

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: I don’t think it is especially the case by the way-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: That’s just not true. People-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: Pete if you want to talk to some of the women on my campaign, what you will see is the most ugly, sexist, racist attacks that are… I won’t even describe them here, they’re so disgusting. And let me say something else about this, not being too paranoid. All of us remember 2016 and what we remember his efforts by Russians and others to try to interfere in our election and divide us up. I’m not saying that’s happening, but it would not shock me. I saw some of those tweets regarding the Culinary Workers Union. I have a 30 year, 100% pro-union voting record. Do you think I would support or anybody supports me, would be attacking union leaders? It’s not thinkable.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: But leadership is about what you draw out of people. It’s about how you inspire people to act. And right now we’re in this toxic political environment. Leadership isn’t just about policy. I think, at least in broad terms, we’re largely pulling in the same direction on policy. But leadership is also about how you motivate people to treat other people and I think you have to accept some responsibility and ask yourself what it is about your campaign and in particular that seems to be motivating this behavior more than others? Because in order to turn the page-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: I have an idea. I have an idea of how we can stop sexism on the internet. We could nominate a woman for candidate for President of the United States. I think that might go a long way, if we showed our stuff as a party. And the other thing I’m going to talk about is really what is at the core of this issue between Senator Sanders and the Culinary Union. And that is this, these are hardworking people. Housekeepers, like Elizabeth and I met with last night, who have healthcare plans that have been negotiated over time, sweat and blood. And that is the truth for so many Americans right now-

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Hallie Jackson
speech: Senator thank you.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: There are 149 million Americans that would lose their current health insurance under Senator Sanders’ bill.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Hallie Jackson
speech: Senator thank you.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: That’s what it says on page eight and I don’t think we should forget that.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Hallie Jackson
speech: On that note, I want to turn it over to my colleague Chuck Todd.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Chuck Todd
speech: Senator Sanders, I’m going to stay on this topic, on this issue with the Culinary Union. Obviously their leaders are warning their members about that your health care plan will take away their healthcare plan, take away private insurance completely. There are some Democrats who like you a lot, but worry that this plan, Medicare-for-all, is going to take away private insurance and that it goes too far. Are they right?

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: No. Let me be very clear, two points. For a hundred years, from Teddy Roosevelt to Barack Obama, this country has been talking about the need to guarantee health care for people. And yet today, despite spending twice as much per capita, Chuck, twice as much as any other major country on earth, we got 87 million who are uninsured or under insured. We got over 60,000 people who die every year because they don’t get to a doctor on time. We’re getting ripped off outrageously by the greed and corruption of the pharmaceutical industry, which in some cases charges us 10 times more for the same drugs because of their price fixing. 500,000 people go bankrupt every year because they can’t afford medical bills. So let me be very clear, to my good friends in the Culinary Workers Union, a great union, I will never sign a bill that will reduce the health care benefits they have. We will only expand it, for them, for every union in America and for the working class of this country.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Chuck Todd
speech: Senator Warren, you were all in on Medicare-for-all and then you have since came up with a transition plan. Is it because of the impact on unions?

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: So I want to be clear. I’ve been to the Culinary Unions’ healthcare facilities, they’re terrific. You don’t want to shut them down, you want to expand them. You want to see them all across Nevada and all across this country. But we need to get everybody’s healthcare plan out here. Mayor Buttigieg really has a slogan that was thought up by his consultants, to paper over a thin version of a plan that would leave millions of people unable to afford their healthcare. It’s not a plan, it’s a PowerPoint. And Amy’s plan is even less, it’s like a Post-it Note, insert plan here. Bernie has started very much, has a good start.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: But instead of expanding and bringing in more people to help, instead his campaign relentlessly attacks everyone who asks a question or tries to fill in details about how to actually make this work. And then his own advisor’s say, “Eh, probably won’t happen anyway.” Look, healthcare is a crisis in this country. My approach to this is we need as much help for as many people as quickly as possible and bring in as many supporters as we can. And if we don’t get it all the first time, take the win and come back into the fight to ask for more.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Chuck Todd
speech: I promise guys, I’m going to get everybody in.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: People need our help on this.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Chuck Todd
speech: I got you. Mayor Buttigieg, I think she named checked you first. I’ll let you go first.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: She name checked me second.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Chuck Todd
speech: Yes. Well, okay. I think Amy’s second.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: I’m more of a Microsoft Word guy. And if you look at my plan, I don’t know if there are any PowerPoints on it, but you can definitely find the document on peteforamerica.com. And you’ll see that it is a plan that solves the problem, makes sure there is no such thing as an uninsured American and does it without kicking anybody off the plan that they have. This idea that the union members don’t know what’s good for them is the exact kind of condescension and arrogance that makes people skeptical of the policies we’ve been putting forward.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
speech: Here we have a plan that the majority of Americans support. Do you realize how historic that is? That the American people are ready in a way, far beyond what was true even 10 years ago and what was available to President Obama at the time. There’s a powerful American majority ready to undertake the biggest, most progressive reform we’ve had in healthcare in 50 years, just so long as we don’t force it on anybody. What is wrong with that?

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
speech: Can I respond to that? [crosstalk 00:20:20]

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Chuck Todd
speech: Let me get Senator Klobuchar and then I’ll have you respond. All right, Senator Klobuchar.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Bernie Sanders
speech: [inaudible 00:20:24].

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Chuck Todd
speech: I think the Post-it Note came first, Senator. [crosstalk 00:20:28]

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: I must say personal offense since post it notes were invented in my state. [crosstalk 00:00:20:38]. Okay. So my plan is a public option and according to all the studies out there, it would reduce premiums for 12 million people immediately. It would expand coverage for about that same number. It is a significant thing, it is what Barack Obama wanted to do from the very beginning. And the way I look at it since we’re in Vegas, when it comes to your plan, Elizabeth and Bernie’s on Medicare-for-all, you don’t put your money on a number that’s not even on the wheel.

debate_name: Democratic Debate Transcript: Las Vegas, Nevada Debate
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
speech: And why is Medicare-for-all not on the wheel? Why is it not on the wheel? Because two thirds of the democratic Senators are not even on that bill, because a bunch of the new House members that got elected see the problems with blowing up the Affordable Care Act. They see it right in front of them. And the truth is that when you see some troubled waters, you don’t blow up a bridge, you build one.
